The number needed to treat (NNT) is a measure that indicates how many patients need to be treated with a particular therapy to prevent one additional bad outcome (or to promote one additional good outcome). It is calculated as the inverse of the absolute risk reduction (ARR). The ARR is calculated as the difference in the event rates between the control group and the treatment group. In this case, the event is death from cardiac causes. The event rate for Medication 1 is 134/1500 = 0.0893 (or 8.93%) The event rate for Medication 2 is 210/1500 = 0.14 (or 14%) So, the ARR = 0.14 - 0.0893 = 0.0507 (or 5.07%) Finally, the NNT = 1/ARR = 1/0.0507 = 19.72, which rounds to 20. So, the NNT for the primary endpoint of death from cardiac causes is 20.
